@WordofJohnGuam @itsmemichellev The Guam Civil Defense Act of 1951 predates Guam Code Annotated and the 1976 court case. Laws in GCA and the decision in Gayle v. Governor of Guam would supersede this Act. We are following guidance from the AG.

In order to strengthen enforcement of Executive Orders, legislation is needed. This conclusion was made in consultation with the Attorney General and my legal counsel. I know there is a desire for stricter rules, but the District Court set precedence that we must follow.

There is no justification for any elected official to disobey the laws of Guam. The need is immediate for this legislation, and we will work as swiftly as possible with the Legislature to enact laws to strengthen enforcement during PH emergencies. https://t.co/FE7w9CTy9x
@Apochryphal @WordofJohnGuam Power to restrict movement is permitted under drills or attacks. The court decided that this does not apply in other forms of states of emergencies.

Our current law does not allow me to enact fines and penalties for those who disobey an executive order. For stricter enforcement, the enabling power must come from the legislature. We will work closely with them to ensure that we can do this within a PH emergency. https://t.co/hj2M6cKuNB

@WordofJohnGuam The court‚Äôs decision was enforcement of curfew and, in general, the restriction of movement is not inherently in the Governor‚Äôs authority as provided in the OA. The authority must be provided by the Legislature.

Unfortunately, I do not have the authority to impose a lockdown. This was decided through Gayle v. Governor of Guam 1976. The court decided that such policing power was not in the Organic Act, and it must be granted from the Legislature. https://t.co/12PikhFmjX

Through EO 2020-07, you cannot be evicted during this public health emergency. And we are working with federal partners to ensure you will get the help you need. If you have any questions regarding employment or welfare benefits, you can 311 and someone can assist you. https://t.co/VBeFQREbmP

@guinaiya671 According to the AG, the ability to enact checkpoints under a PH emergency must come from the legislature. Present measure will remain, but checkpoints will no longer be pursued until legislation is enacted.
According to the AG, the governor does not have this authority. In order to enact such strict measures, the legislature must enact legislation. https://t.co/liSh6OeeBz

It is with great sadness that I must report a fourth death related to COVID-19. Jeff and I send our deepest condolences to her family and everyone who loved her. While COVID-19 has taken so much from so many, it can never rob us of who we are to each other.

Today, we mourn our first COVID-19 related death. Now more than ever, I urge everyone in the community to help one another, educate one another, and continue to make sacrifices to help prevent the spread of the virus.

Monitored home isolation frees space for acute care patients, i.e. those with respiratory disorders. Home isolation also lessens the potential infection of frontline health professionals. To flatten the curve, the decisions we make now are critical to preserving our resources.

Our COVID-19 Isolation Facility is ready to receive the 9 individuals who tested positive for COVID-19 but whose symptoms did not require acute care. During this temporary transition, they were frequently monitored by DPHSS in accordance to CDC guidelines.
Everyone is urged to follow the Social Isolation Directive as outlined in EO2020-04 and EO2020-05. Stay home and limit your movements. Everyone needs to do their part to minimize the spread.

Today, we tested 19 individuals for COVID-19. 2 tested positive and 17 tested negative. 

A total of 100 tests have been performed with conclusive results. To date, a total of 14 cases tested positive and 86 cases tested negative. All 14 confirmed cases remain in isolation.
DPHSS has released further guidance about our Social Isolation Directive. https://t.co/PMZ02yljwl

I will be increasing protection measures for the island. Effective Friday, March 20th at noon, all public spaces in which people come together for food and beverage, entertainment, recreation, and leisure will be closed until March 30th. Further guidance will be provided.

We have three new cases of COVID-19 on Guam. A total of 65 tests were performed from March 12, 2020 through March 18, 2020. To date, a total of eight cases tested positive and 57 cases tested negative for COVID-19.

While I cannot ban flights, I‚Äôve instituted Mandatory Quarantine Protocols for travelers entering Guam. As this is an evolving process, these guidelines are subject to revision. https://t.co/vW6ix3rSFv
@Jenn50291467 Yes, you will be quarantined in your hotel for 14 days or for the duration of your trip. We hope this will help minimize the spread of COVID-19 on Guam.
Today, I signed Executive Order 2020-04, which closes all non-essential GovGuam offices, closes all public and private schools, and prohibits large gatherings effective TODAY, March 16, 2020.

The government is doing what we can, but we need your help too. Based on simulations, extensive (and even moderate) social distancing outperforms attempted forced quarantine methods. If we can minimize the amount of contact we have, the virus has less opportunity to spread.

Effective this morning, March 16, 2020, nonessential Government of Guam operations will be shutdown for two weeks to allow DPHSS and our CDC partners to investigate and mitigate the spread of COVID-19.

While I do not have the authority to ban travel from an FAA facility, I strongly urge everyone to avoid travel to the Philippines and other affected areas. If you recently traveled to an affected area, please quarantine yourself for no less than 14 days.

We have three confirmed cases of COVID-19 on Guam. Please be aware that all social gatherings of 100 people or more will be cancelled after Wednesday. I strongly urge the public to practice social distancing and avoid close contact.

I have ordered the closure of all public senior centers by close of business Wednesday, March 18, 2020. Furthermore, any social event for 100 people or more will also be canceled, effective Wednesday at 5 p.m. These mandates will remain in place as necessary.
While no cases of COVID-19 have been identified on Guam, I have declared a Public Health Emergency in order to safeguard the community and general welfare of the island.
